moves.3... d5 4. cxd5: This is almost a reflex move as the English opening allows black to build a centre before destroying it.  So this is the most direct application of that idea
moves.4... Nxd5 5. Bg2 Nxc3 6. bxc3: and black has effectively exchanged his centre pawn for my b-pawn.  Not a great idea in my opinion
moves.8. Ng1: opening the diagonal for the B and allowing the N to find a safer home
moves.8... f5 9. Nh3 Be6 10. Rb1: much better would have been d3 to further open the diagonal  Or 0-0 and get the K to safety
moves.10... Rb8: slightly better was Qd7 giving teh chance of 0-0-0 getting the K to safety and making a much more complex game
moves.11. d3 Bxa2 12. Rb2: should have played Rb5 hitting a target that could not just move away
moves.12... Bf7 13. Qa4: Qa4 temporarily dissuades black from exd which would break up my centre pawns and expose the K before it castled
moves.13... Qf6 14. O-O: Alittle late but now i can relax and plan
moves.14... Qxc3: i commented to my opponent about pawn pinching and he said 'what have i got to lose?'  well as we shall see with the Q isolated out of place - quite a lot
moves.15. Ng5 Bg8: why guard a pawn that is well protected?  Qa5 would have forced the issue and prevented the moves that follow
moves.17. Qa1: but i prefer to keep my Q on the a-file as part of my attack
moves.17... h6: attacking a piece that is not even involved in the action.  Qa6 would have prevented the threatened carnage
moves.18. exf5: and realising the size of the attack black resigns.
